senses.de: To make sure that something is true or accurate
senses.ex: I have to verify my answers before submitting the exam.

Tips.title: Accuracy Importance
Tips.description: Use 'verify' when accuracy is crucial and you're checking for correctness.
Tips.example: Banks must verify financial transactions for accuracy.

Tips.title: Cross-Checking Process
Tips.description: 'Verify' implies a process of cross-checking information against a reliable source.
Tips.example: We need to verify these figures with the official report.

Tips.title: Beyond Doubt
Tips.description: Using 'verify' suggests eliminating all doubt about information or a fact.
Tips.example: Can you verify whether this is the latest version?

senses.ex: The scientist was able to verify the existence of the new species.

Tips.title: Fact Confirmation
Tips.description: 'Verify' is often used when a factual claim or existence must be confirmed with evidence.
Tips.example: Archaeologists must verify the age of discovered artifacts.

senses.de: In computing, to ensure that input data is valid
senses.ex: The system will verify the user's login details.

Tips.title: System Checks
Tips.description: In computing, 'verify' refers to automated checks by software on data validity.
Tips.example: The email system verifies that addresses are formatted correctly.

Tips.title: Prevent Mistakes
Tips.description: In computing, verification is essential to prevent data errors or security breaches.
Tips.example: The software verifies that the password is strong enough.

senses.de: In law, to swear to the truth of a document under oath
senses.ex: You are required to verify your statement in court.

Tips.title: Legal Truthfulness
Tips.description: Use 'verify' to describe the act of legally confirming the truthfulness of a statement.
Tips.example: Witnesses may have to verify their testimonies with evidence.

Tips.title: Swagger in Certainty
Tips.description: In legal contexts, 'verify' shows a high level of certainty, since it involves an oath.
Tips.example: The notary verified the authenticity of the document.

Attest.wordDefinition:
Attest means to provide evidence or testify to something, especially in writing. It often refers to a formal or legal document, such as signing an affidavit to confirm that something is true.

Attest tends to be more focused on providing evidence in a formal or legal sense, while verify is more about checking or confirming facts.

For example, a witness might attest to the authenticity of a signature on a legal document, while a bank might verify that someone's account balance is accurate.

Authenticate.wordDefinition:
Authenticate means to confirm or establish the identity or origin of something or someone. For example, you might use a password or fingerprint to authenticate yourself when logging in to an account.

So, in short, authenticate is used to confirm identity or origin, while verify is used to confirm truth or accuracy.

Certify.wordDefinition:
‘Certify’ means to confirm that something meets a particular standard or requirement, usually by issuing or giving a certificate or accreditation.

For example, a school or university might certify that a student has successfully completed a course of study.

Confirm.wordDefinition:
The main difference between the words confirm and verify is that confirm means to make sure something that you already know is true or to agree with something that someone else has said or told you.

For example, if you receive an email from a friend inviting you to a party on Saturday, you might reply "I will confirm my attendance with you tomorrow" which means you will let them know for sure if you are able to go to the party or not.

Verify means to check if something is true or correct. For example, if you receive an email from your bank asking you to verify your identity by answering some security questions, you might need to confirm your name, address, and date of birth to prove that it's really you.

To sum up, confirm is used when you already know something and want to make it certain, while verify is used when you need to check if something is true or correct.

Corroborate.wordDefinition:
The words corroborate and verify both mean to confirm or prove something.

However, corroborate is used when you have additional evidence that supports or confirms something that is already believed to be true.

It is used when you need to confirm facts or details. Corroborate is for adding extra confirmation to something that is already believed to be true, and verify is for checking the accuracy or truthfulness of something.

Establish.wordDefinition:
Establish means to create, set up or provide evidence to make something official or recognized.

It is used when starting something new, like a company, a law or a tradition. For example, "the government established a new law to protect animals.".

In simpler terms, establishing means creating something new or making it official, while verifying means checking if something is true or accurate.

Substantiate.wordDefinition:
Substantiate means to provide evidence or proof that something is true, valid, or accurate. This means that you have to show that something is real or genuine by providing actual facts and details to support it.

For example, if you're trying to prove that your theory is correct, you need to substantiate it by providing evidence that supports your claims.

You would use the word substantiate when you need to prove the truth or validity of something, while you would use the word verify when you need to confirm or check the accuracy of something.

Validate.wordDefinition:
Validate means to confirm or prove the accuracy or truth of something. This term is usually used when you need to make sure that what you're looking at is true, and to check if it meets specific standards or requirements.

For example, if you're a teacher and you need to grade a student's exam, you might validate their answers to ensure they are correct and meet the academic standards they need to pass.

So, while both words deal with checking or confirming something, validate refers to accuracy or standards, while verify refers to authenticity or identification.
